paper_abstract: We present algorithmic, complexity and implementation results concerning real root isolation of integer univariate polynomials using the continued fraction expansion of real algebraic numbers. One motivation is to explain the method's good performance in practice. We derive an expected complexity bound of (O) over tilde (B) (d(6) + d(4)tau(2)), where d is the polynomial degree and tau bounds the coefficient bit size, using a standard bound on the expected bit size of the integers in the continued fraction expansion, thus matching the current worst-case complexity bound for real root isolation by exact methods (Sturm, Descartes and Bernstein subdivision). Moreover, using a homothetic transformation we improve the expected complexity bound to (O) over tilde (B) (d(3) tau). We compute the multiplicities within the same complexity and extend the algorithm to non-square-free polynomials. Finally, we present an open-source C++ implementation in the algebraic library SYNAPS, and illustrate its completeness and efficiency as compared to some other available software. For this we use polynomials with coefficient bit size up to 8000 bits and degree up to 1000. (c) 2008 Published by Elsevier B.V.
paper_title: On the complexity of real root isolation using continued fractions
